title: Shia LaBeouf was told he 'had PTSD' from his years working as a child star
text:
Shia LaBeouf has admitted he was diagnosed with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD).

The 33-year-old Transformers star spoke about the condition on The Hollywood Reporter's Awards Chatter podcast on Tuesday - and says it developed from his time as a child actor in Hollywood.

'I just thought I was an alcoholic,' admitted LaBeouf during the interview.

Shia LaBeouf has admitted he was diagnosed with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) in a recent podcast. Seen here on Tuesday

Shia's revelation came during a stint in court-ordered rehab, in the wake of a 2017 altercation with an undercover police officer in Savannah, Georgia.

'It was the first time I’d been told I had PSTD,' said the Disturbia star on the podcast.

'I just thought I was an alcoholic, like, a true-blue drunk and I needed to deal with that,' he continued.

'I knew it was an issue but didn’t know there was this extra whole other thing that was hindering my ability to have any peace in my life and my ability to deal with people.'

The 33-year-old Transformers star spoke about the condition on The Hollywood Reporter's Awards Chatter podcast on Tuesday - and says it developed from his time as a child actor in Hollywood. Seen here in an early role in Disney's Even Stevens

Shia's troubling times as a child actor in Hollywood are chronicled in his yet-to-be-released autobiographical film, Honey Boy.

The film -which was written by and stars LaBeouf- is about Shia's relationship with his father and the strain that developed when the actor's family became dependent on money from his acting career.

'In a very simple way, to me, having money meant having a family,' he revealed.

'The more money I had, the more I could have my family around. That’s just how I equated it.'

Shia's troubling times as a child actor in Hollywood are chronicled in his yet-to-be-released autobiographical film, Honey Boy

Just weeks before Honey Boy hits theaters, LaBeouf has set up a new film project.

The Angeleno actor and writer has signed on to star in Pieces of a Woman alongside British actress Vanessa Kirby, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

Production is scheduled to begin on the film this coming December in Montreal, though no release plans have been given.

New project: Just weeks before Honey Boy hits theaters, LaBeouf has set up a new film project: Pieces of a Woman

The Pieces of a Woman story follows a home birth that turns tragic, as the grieving woman tries to come to terms with her loss.

She must also deal with the ramifications of her terrible loss with her husband, while also dealing with her estranged mother.

While no roles were specified, Kirby will most likely play the grieving mother and LaBeouf the husband, though those roles haven't been confirmed.

Recent films: Both LaBeouf and Kirby are coming off recent films, with LaBeouf starring in The Peanut Butter Falcon and Kirby in Hobbs and Show, which both debuted in August

Kornél Mundruczó (White God) is attached to direct Pieces of a Woman from a script by Kata Weber, who wrote White God and Mundruczo's 2017 film Jupiter's Moon.

Kevin Turen and Ashley Levinson will produce for Little Lamb Studios, a division of Bron Studios that produced the hit HBO show Euphoria, with Arrival producer Aaron Ryder.

Bron's Aaron L. Gilbert and Euphoria creator Sam Levinson will executive produce with Viktória Petrányi, Jason Cloth and Stuart Manashil.

Coming soon: Kirby will next be seen in Mr. Jones, alongside Peter Sarsgaard, which is currently hitting the festival circuit and doesn't have a release date yet

Both LaBeouf and Kirby are coming off recent films, with LaBeouf starring in The Peanut Butter Falcon and Kirby in Hobbs and Show, which both debuted in August.

Kirby will next be seen in Mr. Jones, alongside Peter Sarsgaard, which is currently hitting the festival circuit and doesn't have a release date yet.

LaBeouf also stars in The Tax Collector, which is currently in post-production, where he stars alongside George Lopez and Lana Parilla.

The Tax Collector also reunites LaBeouf with writer-director David Fury, who directed LaBeouf in the 2014 World War II film Fury.

Kirby also stars in The World To Come with Katherine Waterston and Casey Affleck and an untitled project from filmmaker Adam Leon.
